body: The rate of infant deaths in New York City dropped to another record low -- 6.1 deaths out of 1,000 live births -- in 2001, down from 6.7 deaths a year earlier, according to the latest data from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Central Harlem had the highest rate, at 13.1, up from 10.3 in 2000. The rate in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Infant Survival Improving

title: A CRIME REVISITED: VOICES; City Reminded of Fears It Believed It Left Behind

body: FLASHBACKS often occur at the strangest moments. At 5 p.m. yesterday I'd just completed walking my first New York City Marathon. Suddenly I had a
title: Sports of The Times; Walking the Course Is a Salute to City Life

title: URBAN TACTICS; Latest Exit to Brooklyn

author: Jim Nelson is an executive editor at GQ.
body: There are countless reasons that certain neighborhoods become hip -- why Fort Greene, say, or NoLIta suddenly buzzes with a new energy. And in the constant flux of the city, it's difficult to pinpoint the moment any newly revived neighborhood turns that vital corner. But something happened on Clinton Street three and a half years ago, something
title: Hip-ification

body: 1910's: Greenwich Village is widely known as America's bohemian enclave, with cheap rents, for writers and artists. 1950's: White Horse Tavern in Greenwich Village thrives. The Beats Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac and Robert Frank move farther east in search of space and authenticity. 1960's: St. Mark's Place and Washington Square are loci of the

title: NEXT WAVE REVIEW; A 'Medea' Fit for the World of Today

title: Academy of Music in the Land of Sweets

title: F.Y.I.

title: $25 AND UNDER; Beneath Those Frogs' Legs Beats the Heart of a Bistro

title: For Officers, 4 Cases of Gunfire in 5 Hours

He and other members of the Dance Theater of Harlem were preparing for a performance in the Evening Stars series in World Trade Plaza. The troupe piled into the
title: Tragedy Kindles Dance of Hope

title: Liberty Bonds to Finance New Brooklyn Offices

body: With uncertainty about how turnout will be affected by the lack of competition in tomorrow's Democratic primary for governor in New York, candidates for local offices spent the weekend retooling their strategies in an effort to get voters to the polls on their behalf. title: New York City's Local Candidates Revamp Strategies

body: When it first opened last December ''The Guys,'' said to be the first play about Sept. 11 to reach the New York stage, was widely expected to last a season, no more. The story it told -- of a captain in the New York City Fire Department and a former journalist struggling together to come up with the right words to describe firefighters killed on
title: Story of Fallen Firefighters Moves From Stage to Screen

body: Of the 18 Civil Court judgeships up for election in New York City this November, only six are being contested in next week's Democratic primary. As a practical matter, that means the remaining dozen seats will be filled by men and women deeply beholden to the party pols who gave them a berth on the Democratic line and a virtually uncontested ride
title: For Civil Court in Brooklyn

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fort Greene; Diversity, Culture and Brownstones, Too

body: SOON after we became New Yorkers two years ago, my husband and I set out on a mission. We stalked the city's dens of cool -- SoHo, Harlem, Fort Greene in Brooklyn -- studying the New York look, determined to remake our bland Midwestern selves into a more chic couple. We both rushed out and bought leather jackets, funky black shoes and the
title: COPING; Who Knew That a Baby Could Be the Key to the City?

title: Residential Real Estate; 2 Brooklyn Business Sites Converting

title: FILM; An Initiate in the Night Rhythms of Tunis

body: One man was killed by gunfire and another shot in the leg last night in front of a building in Brooklyn, the police said. One of the men was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead about two
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Men Shot, One Dies

body: Nine people were shot in two separate incidents in Brooklyn early yesterday, including a 15-year-old boy who later died after an attack the police said was linked to a killing in May. Three men were also shot in the incident that left the boy dead, the police said. The shooting occurred about 1:30 a.m. on Decatur Street near Wilson Avenue in
title: Teenager Killed and 8 Hurt In Two Brooklyn Shootings

body: An article on Aug. 7 about New York City residents who were enjoying a break in the heat wave referred incorrectly to a structure in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, near a spot where teenagers were playing on steps. It is the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument, a Doric column, not an obelisk.
title: Corrections

body: Austen at Auction A rare first edition of Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice'' was sold at auction in Edinburgh last week for more than $62,000, which experts say is a record for the author's work. The sale came as a surprise to the auctioneers, Lyon & Turnbull, who had expected the three-volume set to fetch less than a third of the final price.
title: Footlights

body: On any given morning, Hakeem S. Jeffries can be found at the entrance to one subway station or another in Brooklyn, handing out campaign literature and passionately explaining to anyone who will listen to what he considers the deficiencies of Assemblyman Roger L. title: Rematch Produces Spirited Primary Race for Assembly Seat in Brooklyn

title: PUBLIC LIVES; For Veteran of AIDS Crisis, Politics Can Wait

body: Shops on Atlantic Avenue sell midcentury modern furniture at prices that would suit a SoHo shopkeeper. Bars in Williamsburg, once a haven for artists on a budget, serve the same $10 cosmopolitans found in Manhattan nightspots. So it should come as no surprise that Tim and Nina Zagat, publishers of the ubiquitous Zagat Survey, have released their
title: Brooklyn Gets a Zagat Guide to Call Its Very Own

body: On the Scene His life can only be described as colorful. The son of a prosperous business owner, he served a brief apprenticeship in law, studied painting and became entranced by the new art of photography. His name was Gustave Le Gray (1820- 1884). He was a technical innovator, an influential teacher and an imaginative cameraman. His adventures

body: Daniel Hook knows what it is like to be judged by the color of his skin. It would take no more than a ride on the subway to get the disapproving looks -- the kind that screamed out: stay away. Mr. Hook is 25, black and a lifelong resident of Brooklyn. He wears baggy pants and a baseball cap and has a fondness for silver earrings. ''Some people
title: 9/11 Bridged the Racial Divide, New Yorkers Say, Gingerly

body: Elections for district leader, among the lowliest jobs on the ladder of elective office, seldom attract much attention other than from devotees of politics. But a district leader race in central Brooklyn is creating a stir for its potential impact on the local Democratic Party leadership and the budding prospects of a maverick city councilman. The
title: In Brooklyn, An 'Insurgent' Vs. a Stalwart

body: A man who had previously told investigators that he and a priest had consensual sex 30 years ago, when both were adults, has been arrested and accused of calling the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and threatening to hurt the priest. The man, Sylvester Wilson, 59, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, called the diocese's switchboard about 5 p.m. on
title: Brooklyn Man Is Arrested and Accused of Threats Against a Priest

title: Cheering the Nets, But Without Blushing; Fans Adjust to a Novelty: A Good Season

body: In Queens, cherry trees burst into bloom. At the Bronx Zoo, polar bears wallowed in cool water. And in Brooklyn, among several supine bodies on the grass of Fort Greene Park, Claudia Pearson seemed stunned. ''If it was 85 this morning, how hot can it get when we actually reach summer?'' Ms. Pearson wondered, lying on a brightly patterned sarong.
title: 92 in the Shade (Well, There Was No Shade)

body: THE Brooklyn dining scene has changed drastically in a decade. In a trickle that has swelled to a flood, Manhattan exiles have colonized every available block in formerly fringe areas off Park Slope and Cobble Hill, taking their money and appetites with them. Not surprisingly, a new generation of restaurants has arisen, seemingly overnight, to
title: RESTAURANTS; A Fresh Start For a Pioneer Of Park Slope

body: WE all think we know how gentrification works. Developers and yuppies discover charm in an old neighborhood, and soon the very people who created the neighborhood can't afford it anymore. Janitors and artists are forced out of their homes to make room for lawyers and bankers. This process has been routinely denounced in neighborhoods like Harlem
title: The Big City; The Gentry, Misjudged As Neighbors

body: An article on Saturday about a suspect in a double homicide who the police say escaped from the 88th Precinct station house in Brooklyn on Friday misstated its location. The station is in the Clinton Hill section, not Fort Greene.
title: Corrections

body: The police said last night that they still had not found a suspect in a double homicide who escaped Friday night from a station house in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The suspect, Alexis Vasquez, 22, should be considered very dangerous and possibly armed, the police said. He was left alone, without handcuffs, on the second floor of the 88th Precinct
title: Man Who Fled Police Station Still at Large

title: Bitterness in Brooklyn Diocese Over Abuse Case

title: Young Artist Is Shot to Death In Brooklyn Apartment House

title: Residential Real Estate; Printing Plant Is Transformed to a Condo Building

body: Pick one. ''Cymbeline'' is a comedy in which a character is beheaded. It's a tragedy with a happy ending. It's a history that has elements of time travel. title: THEATER REVIEW; Shakespeare's Game, Without a Score Card

title: HOUSE PROUD; All That's Missing Is the Disco Ball

title: Presbyterians Reject Amendment on Gay Ministers

body: BARRY ALTERMAN plays three roles with the Mark Morris Dance Group. He regularly appears as both the obnoxious father in Act One and the obnoxious king in Act Two of ''The Hard Nut,'' Mr. Morris's dark, delirious version of ''The Nutcracker.'' Although these are mime roles, Mr. Alterman plays them with such vehemence that he has injured himself.

body: Theater ''KNOCK KNOCK KNOCK, ANYBODY HOME?,'' a series of skits, including one about a glove lost in the big city, will be told with music, comedy and movement by the Paper Bag Players at the Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. Saturdays at 2 p.m. and Sundays at 1 and 3 p.m. Through March 3. Tickets: $15
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: This is Melanie Brown's second year as a teacher, and her second year teaching the same children, moving up with them from fourth to fifth grade to provide consistency and build on the personal relationship between teacher and students. body: All of the more than 700 seats were filled and 200 people stood along the sides of the auditorium at Public School 218 in Washington Heights on Sunday to see Miguel Martinez sworn in as the neighborhood's new city councilman. title: We Solemnly, Merrily Swear; Newly Elected Officials Celebrate With Pageantry

body: A scene that perfectly illustrated A. Gifford Miller's approach to politics unfolded two years ago outside a Brooklyn elementary school. There he was, a councilman from Manhattan's Upper East Side, handing out campaign literature for an entire morning for Roger L. Green, an assemblyman from Fort Greene. body: Performances of work by Martha Graham have been hard to come by, especially in New York, Graham's home base, since the start of a bitter 19-month struggle over the rights to Graham's name and choreographic repertory. Each side in the dispute -- the Martha Graham Trust and the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance -- is planning a performance
title: DANCE NOTES; Dueling Tributes To Graham Legacy
